title: 113_s2710
content: The "Philanthropic Enterprise Act of 2014" exempts certain philanthropic business holdings from private foundation excess business holding tax. The "Philanthropic Enterprise Act of 2014" exempts private foundations from excess business holding tax if the business enterprise meets ownership, profit distribution, and independent operation requirements. The "Philanthropic Enterprise Act of 2014" exempts private foundations from excess business holding tax if the business enterprise meets ownership and profit distribution requirements. The private foundation must hold all ownership interests in the business enterprise and profits must be distributed to charity within 120 days after the close of the taxable year. The net operating income of a business enterprise for a taxable year is gross income reduced by deductions, taxes, and a reasonable reserve for working capital. Independent operation requirements are met if maintained throughout the year. The requirements for a private foundation include ensuring that no substantial contributor or their family member is involved in the business enterprise, and the majority of the foundation's board of directors are not connected to the enterprise. The subsection excludes certain deemed private foundations, including funds or organizations treated as private foundations under specific sections, charitable trusts, and trusts described in another section. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2013 for trusts described in section 4947(a)(2). SEC. 3 amends section 512(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to exempt certain payments from unrelated business tax for philanthropic controlled entities. Effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2013.
